titleStmt.title: M48. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 2p
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M48. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 2p

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
For many centuries after (afte) Britain became an island "
the says, "the untamed forest was king."
He goes on to say that amillions of birds, perched on
the top of those matted branches, sang their choruses.
Only the skin clad hunters in the clearings heard the song.
The tree had (ha ) to be felled; and a hut made from its
branches , before the human voice sang too.

By a bank as I lay
Musing myself alone, j hey ho!
A birdes voice
Did me rejoice,
Singing before the day
And me thought in her lay
She said, winter was past, hey ho!

The first songs are out of door songs; because there
was no comfort indoors, little light, and no books.
The voice that broke (brok) the silence (silnec) of the forests was like a
birds voice, singing out of doors. It was the voice of
. He had no comfort indoors, little light
and no books. He had no (n) name. Some one heard the song
and remembered (rmember d) it, for it was later written down. TheThusthe singer
had his audience thus; but the audience was so little
interested in his name that he never thought to give it.
The audience took part too in the song. "Terly, terlow"
they sang: and "By, by lullay" filling in the (th ) pause,
helping out the largermeaning.[ sings because spring has
come; or winter is gone; because (b cause) he loves; because he
is hungry; or lustful; or merry.] Everybody shares the

emotion (emition); & sung and knows the old story of the Nut brown maid.
Anon is sometimes woman; sometimes man; he is the
common voice; He hears of them [illeg.] Anon goes round the country singing.
[He has a very quick eye, connected, for the eye is the
youthful sense, rather with the body than the mind.]
Anon Hehas no house. He lives a roaming out of door
country life, going from village to village,
stopping at (a) the back door ,oftener than at the front,
going along (alojg) grassy paths over the hills. | By choosing a view
carefully to shut out a chimney or a bungalow (bungalwo), we can still
see, in some (osome), or up on some down, what Anon saw.
the bird haunted (ha unted) reed (red) whispering fen; the down covered
with turf; and the scar, long healed, over the downhill
along which Anon came when he made his journeys.
He was garrulous; loose (looe) lipped; taking from other peoples
mouths here a story, there a stanza. But now and again he
as we call (acll) it, an artist; the words are complete; the song
finished.
